text.p: The following Australian economic indicators and events are scheduled for this week.

Mon 0130 Manufact output prices Aug +0.1 pct
Wed 0130 Westpac Consumer sent Oct -1.2 pct

Thu 0130 Manufact input prices Aug -1.3 pct
Thu 0130 Export price index Aug -0.1 pct
Thu 0130 Import price index Aug -0.3 pct

QUESTION OF THE WEEK - Economists were asked on their near term outlook for the labour market. Unemployment was seen remaining trapped around 8.5 percent or higher -- even those at the lower end of forecasts said the forecast was weighted towards 8.5 percent rather than representing a move towards 8.0 percent by year's end. Employment growth was generally seen only remaining strong enough to meet new entrants to the labour force, with a recovery in employment not seen until 1997.

The stalling labour market, coupled with the moderation in inflation and wages, was a factor behind the July 31 50 basis point rate cut and continuing softness would maintain expectations of another reduction, economists said.
Employ Unemp Part Ave mthly Unemp House
Rate Rate emp - Q4 end 96 Fin
Soc Generale flat 8.5 63.6 n/f n/f n/f

LABOUR FORCE - The expected reversal of the 10,000 census workers included in the August data, and some expectation that the series is due for a fall after five consecutive rises, has led to forecasts of neagtive employment growth in September. However, the jump in the participation rate during August is expected to be unwound, which should see the unemployment rate drop back towards 8.5 percent. A weak number would bring the
interest rate cut bulls in the market to the fore, economists said. The median forecast would leave employment up 27,400 on last December -- or just over 3,000 jobs per month this year.

HOUSING FINANCE - Only a slight fall is expected in August housing finance approvals, despite the fact they rose by 16.0 percent in July. Australian Bankers Association numbers suggest a fairly flat figure, economists said. With some signs of recovery appearing in both the finance and building approvals numbers, a slight fall may be taken as evidence that the sector may be recovering from early 1997.
